title: Understanding Gynaecological Ultrasound
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value: A gynaecological (pelvic) ultrasound is a safe test that uses sound waves to examine the uterus, ovaries and other pelvic organs. Some scans may feel slightly uncomfortable, but they are not usually painful

items.title: How It Works
items.description: Ultrasound works by using sound waves to create real-time images of the inside of the body. It does not use radiation, so it’s considered very safe, and it allows the clinician to view pelvic organs live during the scan. This makes it a key diagnostic tool for assessing and monitoring many gynaecological conditions.

items.title: What We Can See
items.description: During the scan, we can assess the size and shape of the uterus, examine the ovaries and any developing follicles, and measure the thickness of the endometrial (womb) lining. It can also help identify cysts, fibroids, or other abnormalities, and in some cases, the fallopian tubes may be visible if they are enlarged or contain fluid.

sections.cardTitle: Why You Might Need an Ultrasound

items.title: Detect possible miscarriage or retained tissue

content.title: Important Note
content.description: If the womb lining appears thicker than expected, especially if you have symptoms such as abnormal bleeding, you may be offered a hysteroscopy and biopsy to investigate further. This is a precaution to rule out significant problems and protect your health.

items.title: Transabdominal Ultrasound
items.description: The probe is placed on your lower tummy. Gives a broad view of pelvic organs. Non-invasive external scan. May require full bladder.

items.title: Transvaginal Ultrasound
description: A transvaginal ultrasound is performed by gently inserting the probe into the vagina, allowing closer and more detailed images of the pelvic organs. It is commonly used in fertility assessments and provides clearer views, especially during early pregnancy.

content.title: Safety Information
content.description: Both types of ultrasound are considered very safe. Transabdominal scans are painless, while transvaginal scans may cause mild discomfort for some people. Diagnostic ultrasound does not use radiation, and no harmful effects have been shown at the levels used in medical imaging.

steps: Positioning — You'll lie on an examination couch in a comfortable position
Gel Application — A small amount of warm gel is placed on your lower abdomen
Scanning — The ultrasound probe is moved gently across the skin
Transvaginal (if needed) — For internal scan, probe is covered with sheath and lubricated before gentle insertion

items.title: Duration
items.description: The scan usually takes about 10-15 minutes

items.title: Comfort
items.description: Most people find the scan comfortable. Transvaginal scans may cause mild discomfort but are not usually painful.

items.title: Immediate Recovery
items.description: You can go straight back to normal activities. No restrictions on eating or drinking. No recovery time needed.

items.title: Your Results
items.description: A specialist will interpret your results. Results will be discussed with you. Follow-up tests arranged if needed. Treatment options explained if required.

content.title: Safety Assurance
content.description: Diagnostic ultrasound is considered very safe and does not use radiation. No harmful effects have been shown at the levels used in medical imaging. Scans can be repeated when medically necessary.

items.title: What if something is found?
items.content: If anything unusual is found, your doctor will discuss treatment options or any follow-up procedures with you. Additional tests may be required based on findings.
